title: Anaconda Distribution
sub_title: Get Python and the Anaconda distribution which includes almost all of the libraries you will need to get started.

title: IPython
sub_title: Learn about IPython and IPython Notebooks.

title: Python For Data Mining
sub_title: Read my introduction post on how to use Python for data mining.

title: Coursera Machine Learning
sub_title: This excellent course is probably the most popular. Taught by Andrew Ng who is now the Chief Scientist at Baidu; great coverage of topics. I would definitely recommend starting here for for online courses.

title: Harvard Data Science
sub_title: I love this course because it uses Python. Also has a good coverage of topics and a great github repo of code. Great place to learn data science using Python.

title: Analyzing Big Data With Twitter
sub_title: This course comes from the information school at UC Berkeley. I have not finished this course, but the content looks great and it comes highly recommended. Great way to get started with Twitter data.

title: The Open Source Data Science Masters
sub_title: This is an awesome site that basically lays out many of the areas of data science and provides links to books, courses, and tutorials to help learn those subjects. And it is open source so you can contribute!

title: Data Analysis
sub_title: At 310+ hours, this course has a ton of material and is organized very well, so you can easily dig into areas that interest you. It even has optional tracks such as visualizing data and analyzing social networks.

title: Yhat Blog
sub_title: The Yhat blog always seems to have awesome articles on data science. Great place to learn and see some cool projects.

title: DataTau
sub_title: DataTau is like the Hacker News of data science. The site isn't nearly as active as Hacker News, but often has some nice posts. Would be cool to help it to continue to grow.

title: Mike Bostock
sub_title: One of the developers of D3.js - this guy is the king of interactive visualization. Check out his stuff and be amazed. He also posts amazing tutorials.

title: While My MCMC Gently Samples
sub_title: Thomas Wiecki is very skilled at writing tutorials. Focuses mostly on Python and Bayesian methods; best place to learn how to use Python for Bayesian statistics.

title: Sebastian Raschka
sub_title: Sebastian has a great blog with really well explained data science posts with lots of Python code. He is also a great person to follow on Twitter.

title: Partially Derivative
sub_title: Great podcast that covers data science news of the week in a very entertaining fashion. Great way to keep up with data related stories.

title: Talking Machines
sub_title: A podcast focused more on machine learning research. Some great interviews with leading researchers.

title: O'Reilly Data Show
sub_title: Tends to focus on interviews with people from industry. Provides some great insights into how data science is being used in industry.

title: An Introduction to Statistical Learning
sub_title: If I were to pick a book to start with, this would be it. Great explanations of most of the important topics with R code. For a more advanced version, check out The Elements of Statistical Learning.

title: Applied Predictive Modeling
sub_title: As stated, this is a very applied book with R code. Similar to Introduction to Statistical Learning, but hits more on certain topics such as data pre-processing.

title: Doing Bayesian Data Analysis
sub_title: By far the best book I have read on how to do Bayesian Data Analysis that doesn't assume much prior knowledge. Tons of R code and hits on lots of great topics.

title: Bayesian Methods for Hackers
sub_title: This is the best book I have seen on Bayesian methods using Python. I would recommend learning about Bayesian statistics from Doing Bayesian Data Analysis and then using this book to help learn how to do things in Python.

title: Python for Data Analysis
sub_title: From the creator of Pandas, this is the best book to learn the Python language from a data science perspective. A lot of this information is in the online docs, but still a great resource with data analysis examples.

title: Interactive Data Visualization for the Web
sub_title: By far the best resource I have found to learn how to use D3.js to make sweet visualizations. It assumes little prior knowledge about java script and CSS. Definitely check it out if you enjoy creating visualizations.

title: Core Libraries
sub_title: In my experience, the core data science libraries for Python are pandas, scipy, numpy, matplotlib, scikit-learn, and statsmodels. To learn more about these libraries check out my Introduction to Python for Data Mining post.

title: Seaborn
sub_title: Seaborn is a great visualization library that helps you easily make nicer looking matplotlib graphs as well as provides some additional plots, such as violin plots.

title: PyMC 3
sub_title: PyMC 3 is one of the coolest libraries. It makes doing bayesian statistics super easy and provides a bunch of great functionaliy. Definitely check it out.
